009package imagingbook.core.resource;
010
011import java.io.File;
012import java.io.InputStream;
013import java.net.URL;
014
015/**
016 * <p>
017 * This interface is supposed to be implemented by some enum class that
018 * specifies the root of a resource tree. The following example defines
019 * such an enum type that refers to three images. The path relative 
020 * to the location of the enum class itself must be specified
021 * and images must be stored there.
022 * The enum type must define an appropriate constructor and implement
023 * method {@link #getFileName()}:
024 * </p>
025
026 * <pre>
027 * public enum MyImages implements NamedResource {
028 *      image1("image1.tif"),
029 *      image2("image2.png"),
030 *      image3("jpegs/image3.jpg");
031 * 
032 *      // field to associate the resource's file name
033 *      private final String filename;
034 * 
035 *      &#64;Override
036 *      public String getFileName() {
037 *              return filename;
038 *      }
039 * 
040 *      // constructor
041 *      MyImages(String filename) {
042 *              this.filename = filename;
043 *      }
044 * }</pre>
045 * <p>
046 * By default, resource files are assumed to be placed in a folder
047 * with the same name as the resource class (i.e., "MyImages") relative
048 * to the location of the class.
049 * Resources may then be simply referenced by their enum-name, for example,
050 * </p>
051 * <pre>
052 * URL url = MyImages.image1.getURL();
053 * ImagePlus im = IJ.openImage(url.toString());
054 * </pre>
055 * <p>
056 * The benefit of using a named resource (over specifying resources by path strings) 
057 * is that the resource is guaranteed to exist at compile time (this is assured
058 * by validating the existence of all named resources in the test phase) and can be retrieved
059 * even if located inside a JAR file.
060 * </p>
061 * @see ImageResource
062 * @author WB
063 * @version 2022/08/23
064 */
065public interface NamedResource {
066        
067        /**
068         * Returns the resource directory relative to the implementing class.
069         * The default implementations assumes that this is a single-level directory
070         * with exactly the same name as the implementing class.
071         * Implementations may override this definition to return some other 
072         * relative directory.
073         * 
074         * @return the relative resource directory for the associated resource
075         */
076        public default String getRelativeDirectory() {
077                return this.getClass().getSimpleName();
078        }
079        
080
081        
082        /**
083         * Returns the path to the associated resource relative to the
084         * location of the implementing class.
085         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
086         * 
087         * @return the relative path to the associated resource
088         */
089        public default String getRelativePath() {
090                return getRelativeDirectory() + "/" + getFileName();
091        }
092        
093        /**
094         * Returns the file name for the associated resource.
095         * 
096         * @return the name of the resource file
097         */
098        public String getFileName();
099        
100        /**
101         * Returns the URL to the associated resource.
102         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
103         * 
104         * @return the URL to the associated resource
105         */
106        public default URL getURL() {
107                Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
108                return clazz.getResource(this.getRelativePath());
109        }
110        
111//      @Deprecated
112//      public default URI getURI() {
113//              try {
114//                      return getURL().toURI();
115//              } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
116//                      return null;
117//              }
118//      }
119        
120//      /**
121//       * Returns the {@link Path} to the associated resource object.
122//       * @return the resource's {@link Path} 
123//       */
124//      @Deprecated
125//      public default Path getPath() {
126//              //return toPath(this.getURI());
127//              return Paths.get(getURI());
128//      }
129        
130//      public default URI getURI() {
131//              Class<?> clazz = this.getClass();
132//              String resourceName = getRelativePath();
133//              Objects.requireNonNull(resourceName);
134//              URI uri = null;
135//              if (this.isInsideJar()) {       // (classInsideJar(clazz))
136//                      String classPath = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
137//                      //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
138//                      String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
139//                      String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + resourceName;
140//                      try {
141//                              uri = new URI(compPath);
142//                      } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
143//                              throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
144//                      }       
145//              }
146//              else {  // regular file path
147//                      try {
148//                              URL url = clazz.getResource(resourceName);
149//                              if (url != null) {
150//                                      uri = url.toURI();
151//                              }
152//                      } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
153//                              //do nothing, just return null
154//                      }
155//              }
156//              return uri;
157//      }
158        
159//      /**
160//       * Converts an {@link URI} to a {@link Path} for objects that are either
161//       * in the file system or inside a JAR file.
162//       * 
163//       * @param uri the specified {@link URI}
164//       * @return the associated {@link Path}
165//       */
166//      public static Path toPath(URI uri) {
167//              Path path = null;
168//              String scheme = uri.getScheme();
169//              switch (scheme) {
170//              case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
171//                      FileSystem fs = null;
172//                      try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
173//                              fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
174//                      } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
175//                              // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
176//                      }
177//                      
178//                      if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
179//                              try {
180//                                      Map<String, Object> map = Collections.emptyMap();
181//                                      fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, map);       // FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
182//                              } catch (IOException e) {
183//                                      throw new RuntimeException(e.toString());
184//                              }
185//                      }
186//                      
187//                      String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
188//                      int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
189//                      String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
190//                      path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
191//                      break;
192//              }
193//              case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
194//                      path = Paths.get(uri);
195//                      break;
196//              }
197//              default:
198//                      throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
199//              }
200//              return path;
201//      }
202        
203        /**
204         * Returns true if the associated resource (class) is located inside a JAR file.
205         * 
206         * @return true if inside a JAR file
207         */
208        public default boolean isInsideJar() {
209                URL url = getClass().getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
210                String path = url.getPath();
211                File file = new File(path);
212                return file.isFile();
213        }
214
215//      static boolean classInsideJar(Class<?> clazz) {
216//      URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
217//      String path = url.getPath();
218//      File file = new File(path);
219//      return file.isFile();
220//}
221        
222        /**
223         * Returns an {@link InputStream} for reading from this resource.
224         * See also {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
225         * This method is not supposed to be overridden.
226         * 
227         * @return an {@link InputStream} for the associated resource
228         */
229        public default InputStream getStream() {
230                return getClass().getResourceAsStream(getRelativePath());
231        }
232
233}
